story:
Imagine...

Being a woman or girl in a dusty rural village, walking into an unlit room without access to electricity or running water. You remove all of your clothing and lie down on the cement floor as labor pains wrack your body. You prepare yourself for the most painful event of your life, one that very well might kill you.

There are no drugs to dull your pain, no gloves to protect you from germs, no instruments to monitor your baby's progress, and not a single doctor or nurse nearby. Labor will continue for hours on end, perhaps even days. This is the most natural human phenomenon in the world, yet it's absolutely terrifying. You have lost control of your body. You know of many women and infants in the village who have not survived this.

Once your baby is born she is placed on the ground off to the side while the midwife focuses on you - the one with the better chance of survival. Once you are cleaned up and sleeping she turns her attention to the baby. Hopefully the baby doesn't aspirate amniotic fluid or meconium since there is no bulb syringe to clean out her nose and throat. Hopefully she doesn't need medical attention because none is near. Hopefully she will live.

Background:

Asiri is a small rural village in Ghana, West Africa. As a U.S. Peace Corps volunteer it has been my home for two lovely years. I have spent this time falling in love with the village and giving it everything I have in order to better the lives of the people here who have become my extended family. The community and I have worked on projects in the realms of agriculture, health, education and income generation.

Our focus now is addressing the critical issues of maternal & infant health and obstetrics in the village.

Delivery by a traditional birth attendant or midwife has been the common practice here for as long as the village has existed. Though it is prevalent all over Ghana, there are many aspects of it that are potentially exceedingly damaging and life-threatening to both mother and child. Babies are often pulled out too roughly, causing life-long damage to the child’s body, and aren’t given to the mother to nurse upon delivery. Gloveless fingers inserted into the mother continuously during labour, between the midwife cooking food, caring for children and going about her daily life, readily create infection. Among countless other concerns, there is no testing for diseases, HIV/AIDS, or anything else, as there is for births in proper clinics.

The people of Asiri tried to build a maternity clinic some years ago. They built the foundation and sandcrete block walls that you see below, but then money ran out. Due to endemic poverty, drought and other factors, there are just no funds to complete it. The people have assured me time and time again that if the materials are made available, the entire community will pitch in to construct it.

Mission:

  • To decrease maternal and infant mortality in Asiri
  • To make the birth process in Asiri safer, more comfortable and hygienic
  • To build the capacity of the local midwife and bring in a qualified doctor
  • To decrease teenaged pregnancies & increase family planning
  • To improve pre-natal and ante-natal care
  • To provide free HIV testing and counseling for the entire village

Vision:

The people of Asiri will have a safe, comfortable, clean atmosphere full of knowledgable staff in which to deal with all aspects of delivering and caring for their children and themselves.

Approach:

  • Finish building the maternity clinic
  • Furnish and stock the clinic with equipment and supplies
  • Train the midwife on best practices
  • Teach her how to use the new equipment and supplies
  • Create mother support groups
  • Conduct classes for mothers and young women on nutrition, HIV/AIDS, family planning, general health and infant care

How you can help:

  • Donate funds to help us meet our goal so we can build and furnish the clinic
  • Donate supplies: baby blankets, newborn apparel, medical supplies etc.

    Send them to: 



  • Spread the word! The more people who know about this cause, the more can help!

Funds will be used for:

Building materials: cement, sand, gravel, lumber, electrical wiring materials, nails, doors, windows, hinges, locks, paint, brushes, floor and wall tiles, etc (we already have roofing sheets, iron rods and part of the lumber)

Furniture: delivery beds, chairs, desks, shelves, tables, filing cabinets

Furnishings: ceiling fans, blankets, sheets, curtains, informational posters

Recording supplies: file folders, stationary, pens, record books

Medical Supplies: incubator, oxygen cylinder, drip/infusion pole, baby weighing scale, catgut, standing lamps, refrigerator for medicine, suction bulbs, stethoscope, fetoscope, gloves, surgery instruments, blood pressure cuff, hemostats, specula, forceps, needles, needle holders, catheters, rubber apron, syringes, gauze, disinfectant, episiotomy scissors, long scissors, umbilical scissors, cord clamps, etc

Our funding goal - $14,800 - is the bare bones estimate of what we will need to finish the clinic. Any additional funds will go to stocking extra or better equipment and materials for the clinic, or to training materials/sessions for the midwife and doctor.

 

 

*    *    *    *    *    *    *    *    *    *    *    *    *    *    *    *    *    *    *    *    *  

Perks and Partners

We are fortunate to have the generous contributions of an outstanding non-profit organization here in Ghana called Our Talking Hands and two talented individuals – Robyn Devine and Whitney Smith. They are supporting our project by hand-making (and in the case of the two ladies - donating) the lovely perks that come with this campaign, which are listed on the righthand side of this page and below.

______________________________________________________________________________

 

Robyn Devine – She Makes Hats

Knitting and donating baby hats for the newborns in Asiri

These adorable hats are being knitted as we speak by Robyn Devine. She will donate one to the Asiri clinic for a baby born there for every single $20 donated! A bit about this big-hearted and hard-working knitter...

Robyn Devine knits hats and gives them away. Her hats end up on the heads of Army veterans, brand new babies, and homeless and transient folks. Her hats have been seen all over the internet, worn by bloggers from such diverse areas as minimalism, mommy-blogging, world-traveling and scrap-booking. Robyn blogs at SheMakesHats.com.  Look for your donation hat at http://instagram.com/shemakeshats# 

______________________________________________________________________________

Whitney Smith – Apples and Nanas

Making and Donating Flannel Receiving Blankets for the newborns in Asiri

These precious receiving/swaddling blankets you see below are being made by Whitney Smith, mom of two lil ladies, wife, Gal Friday (during the daytime hours), lover of crafting/sewing, expensive coffee and reality TV! She will donate one blanket to the clinic's newborns for the first 20 donations of $35!

Check out her other handmade baby items through her Etsy Site: www.applesandnanas.etsy.com and Facebook: www.facebook.com/applesandnanas

______________________________________________________________________________

Our Talking Hands (OTH) – A Non-Profit Organization supporting the deaf in Ghana 

Providing lovely handmade crafts that will support both the clinic and their remarkable work with the deaf community in Ghana


Our Talking Hands is a non-profit organization located in Hohoe, Ghana, West Africa, that supports Ghana's deaf community by providing sustainable livelihoods through the making of gorgeous, well-made local crafts.

Their mission:

“Our Talking Hands has two primary goals: to provide our customers with unique, high quality, handmade apparel and to afford Ghana’s deaf community with sustainable livelihoods.

In Ghana, the deaf are at an economic disadvantage. Deaf people are marginalized by stigmas rooted in traditional beliefs and are often relegated to the outskirts of towns. Those lucky enough to be placed in schools are given hope, while many do not have the opportunity to attend schools and remain in their villages and left to a life of hard farming and manual labor. Many people believe that the deaf cannot learn and, therefore, there is no reason to send them to schools. Others believe that deafness is a curse, passed along as punishment for past transgressions. At Our Talking Hands, the deaf and hearing work side by side. We seek to dispel harmful myths while producing some of the finest African arts and crafts in the community.

Our Talking Hands is rooted in the deaf community, but remains open to any artists or groups that commit to working with the deaf community as educators, employers, or mentors. We value independence and wish to empower individuals, but we also strive to promote interdependence through collaboration and inclusion. Proceeds from our sales assist in the development of schools for the deaf in Ghana, with the hopes of growing our mission to include neighboring countries in West Africa. By supporting the local schools in Ghana, we hope to equip the students with the necessary skills to gain employment and become economically independent.”

 

For more information about Our Talking Hands, visit their website at: www.ourtalkinghands.com.

You can also find them on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/0urTalkingHands and

Twitter: https://twitter.com/ourtalkinghands.

 

Check out the perks that are available to you through this campaign from Our Talking Hands!

Reusable Flour Sack Shopping Bag - yours with a donation of $32:

This reusable shopping bag is made from re-purposed flour sacks, and is an excellent example of the resourcefulness we at Our Talking Hands love to encourage! This grocery tote bag is handmade by a seamstress in the small village of Kute, northeast of Hohoe in the Volta Region. This tote has a flat bottom so that more items will comfortably fit inside. It is 16" at the opening and 13" deep. The bottom is 4" x 11". The two carrying straps are 21" long; 1 3/4" wide; a comfortable length to slip over a shoulder on the way home from making your purchases. The tote bags are very light weight cotton and machine washable. Each bag has some variation in wording, but they are essentially the same. Say goodbye to plastic and paper grocery bags--recycle and re-use!!!

Proceeds go to both the maternity clinic and the development of the Volta School for the Deaf.

 

Ghanaian Batik Apron - yours with a donation of $40:

This apron is a unique work of art; no two aprons are alike. It is handcrafted with care by a Master Seamstress, assisting in the development of the tailors and seamstresses at the Volta School for the Deaf in Hohoe, Ghana, West Africa. This apron is made using strips of traditional African Batik. 

Proceeds go to both the maternity clinic and the development of the Volta School for the Deaf.

 

Batik Messenger Bag - yours with a donation of $40:

This messenger bag is handmade by a school mentor, who is assisting in the development of the tailors and seamstresses in the vocational department in Hohoe, Ghana, West Africa. It is fashioned from strips of cotton batik fabric from West Africa, fully lined with a zippered pocket and velcro flap closure. The shoulder strap is reinforced and 42" long, ample length to wear on your shoulder or across your chest. The bag is 10" wide and 12" long, just large enough to carry what you need and the perfect size for carrying a netbook computer. Each bag is a unique work of art, so they differ widely in the color and arrangement of the fabrics. Construction is identical for each bag. 

Proceeds will go to both the maternity clinic and the development of programs for the students at The Volta School for the Deaf.

 

Kente Messenger Bag - yours with a donation of $40:

 

This African Kente Cloth Tablet Messenger Bag is handmade by Vocational Students at The Volta School for the Deaf in Hohoe, Ghana, West Africa. The kente is made into this high quality messenger bag by a school mentor, who is assisting in the development of the tailors and seamstresses in the vocational department.

This messenger bag is fashioned from strips of purple, teal, yellow, pink and black kente cloth, carefully woven by students in a manner that dates back to their ancestors. Kente was originally worn only by the nobility in West Africa and is highly revered today. The bag is fully lined with a zippered pocket and velcro flap closure. The reinforced, 42" shoulder strap is long enough to wear over your shoulder or across your chest. The bag is 10" wide and 12" long, just large enough to carry what you need and the perfect size for carrying a netbook computer or an iPad Tablet Device. 

Proceeds go to both the maternity clinic and the development of the Volta School for the Deaf.

 

Batik Throw Pillow Cover - yours with a donation of $45:

Each pillow cover is a unique work of art, varying slightly--front and back--as they are handmade; handcrafted with care by a Master Seamstress, assisting in the development of the tailors and seamstresses at the Volta School for the Deaf in Hohoe, Ghana, West Africa. This cover is made with narrow strips of traditional African Print on one side and an African cotton batik in three shades of blue on the other. There is a zippered enclosure in which you can insert the pillow form.

Proceeds go to both the maternity clinic and the development of the Volta School for the Deaf.

 

Kente Table Runner - yours with a donation of $45:

These Kente tablerunners are handmade by Vocational Students at The Jamasi School for the Deaf in Jamasi, Ghana, West Africa. They are fashioned from a single 10 inch strip of kente cloth, carefully woven by students in a manner that dates back to their ancestors. Kente cloth was originally worn only by the nobility in West Africa and is highly revered today. The colors in each strip vary. Each reversible runner is 10" wide and 70 " long. The threads used are washable and should clean up nicely. I would suggest handwashing, however.

Proceeds will go to both the maternity clinic and to deaf artisans in Ghana.

 

Sankofa Spiral Sterling Silver Necklace- yours with a donation of $55:

This Sterling Silver Pendant Necklace is made by a local jeweler named Alex in Hohoe, Ghana, West Africa, the home of The Volta School for the Deaf. The pendant depicts the West African Adinkra symbol Sankofa which signifies the importance of returning in time to bring to the present useful past cultural values, which are needed still today. It is believed that progress is based on the right use of the positive contributions of the past. The pendant measures 1 1/8" high (including the bale) by 3/8" wide. The delicate flat long and short cable chain necklace measures 17 1/2" and has a spring ring clasp. 

Alex has offered to mentor the students in the vocational program in jewelry making. We at OTH are looking forward to forging a strong relationship with Alex to further ties between the school and the Hohoe community.

Proceeds will go to both the maternity clinic and to the development and support of programs for the students at The Volta School for the Deaf.

 

Adinkra Crocodile/Turtle Sterling Silver Necklace- yours with a donation of $55:

This Sterling Silver Pendant Necklace is made by a local jeweler named Alex in Hohoe, Ghana, West Africa, the home of The Volta School for the Deaf. The pendant depicts the West African Adinkra symbol of the turtle/crocodile which means "adaptability." It is another logo that is used by "Our Talking Hands." It is quite appropriate, as the deaf community must adapt in a hearing world. The pendant measures 1 1/4" high (including the bale) by 5/8" wide. The delicate flat long and short cable chain necklace measures 17 1/2" and has a spring ring clasp. 

Alex has offered to mentor the students in the vocational program in jewelry making. We at OTH are looking forward to forging a strong relationship with Alex to further ties between the school and the Hohoe community.

Proceeds will go to both the maternity clinic and to the development and support of programs for the students at The Volta School for the Deaf.

As it goes on, we will be posting photos of the students making the handmade perks for this campaign!

______________________________________________________________________________

 

Patchwork Batik blankets handmade by Asiri girls - yours with a donation of $200

As a means of income generation for the local girls and young women of Asiri, together we have created a sewing club. The girls learn quickly and do a terrific job. They will soon be learning how to make their own batik for use in their sewing projects. The first 10 people who donate $200 will receive their own twin-sized patchwork blanket made by the Asiri girls. It will arrive at your door in December of this year, just in time for Christmas! Pictures coming soon!

 

______________________________________________________________________________

Further Information & Contact

To learn more about this project please visit: 

http://changetheworldofone.com/2012/09/27/asiris-maternity-clinic/ 

http://changetheworldofone.com/about/ 

http://stayingonanewcourse.blogspot.com/2013/02/a-shift-in-focus.html

If you have questions, comments or would like more information about this project, please email me at: jasmine.staff@gmail.com  Thank you!!!

From the people of Asiri and myself:

Thank you!!!
story_txt:
Imagine...
Being a woman or girl in a dusty rural village, walking into an unlit room without access to electricity or running water. You remove all of your clothing and lie down on the cement floor as labor pains wrack your body. You prepare yourself for the most painful event of your life, one that very well might kill you.
There are no drugs to dull your pain, no gloves to protect you from germs, no instruments to monitor your baby's progress, and not a single doctor or nurse nearby. Labor will continue for hours on end, perhaps even days. This is the most natural human phenomenon in the world, yet it's absolutely terrifying. You have lost control of your body. You know of many women and infants in the village who have not survived this. Once your baby is born she is placed on the ground off to the side while the midwife focuses on you - the one with the better chance of survival. Once you are cleaned up and sleeping she turns her attention to the baby. Hopefully the baby doesn't aspirate amniotic fluid or meconium since there is no bulb syringe to clean out her nose and throat. Hopefully she doesn't need medical attention because none is near. Hopefully she will live.

Background:
Asiri is a small rural village in Ghana, West Africa. As a U.S. Peace Corps volunteer it has been my home for two lovely years. I have spent this time falling in love with the village and giving it everything I have in order to better the lives of the people here who have become my extended family. The community and I have worked on projects in the realms of agriculture, health, education and income generation.
Our focus now is addressing the critical issues of maternal & infant health and obstetrics in the village.
Delivery by a traditional birth attendant or midwife has been the common practice here for as long as the village has existed. Though it is prevalent all over Ghana, there are many aspects of it that are potentially exceedingly damaging and life-threatening to both mother and child. Babies are often pulled out too roughly, causing life-long damage to the child’s body, and aren’t given to the mother to nurse upon delivery. Gloveless fingers inserted into the mother continuously during labour, between the midwife cooking food, caring for children and going about her daily life, readily create infection. Among countless other concerns, there is no testing for diseases, HIV/AIDS, or anything else, as there is for births in proper clinics.
The people of Asiri tried to build a maternity clinic some years ago. They built the foundation and sandcrete block walls that you see below, but then money ran out. Due to endemic poverty, drought and other factors, there are just no funds to complete it. The people have assured me time and time again that if the materials are made available, the entire community will pitch in to construct it.

Mission:

To decrease maternal and infant mortality in Asiri
To make the birth process in Asiri safer, more comfortable and hygienic
To build the capacity of the local midwife and bring in a qualified doctor
To decrease teenaged pregnancies & increase family planning
To improve pre-natal and ante-natal care
To provide free HIV testing and counseling for the entire village

Vision:
The people of Asiri will have a safe, comfortable, clean atmosphere full of knowledgable staff in which to deal with all aspects of delivering and caring for their children and themselves.
Approach:

Finish building the maternity clinic
Furnish and stock the clinic with equipment and supplies
Train the midwife on best practices
Teach her how to use the new equipment and supplies
Create mother support groups
Conduct classes for mothers and young women on nutrition, HIV/AIDS, family planning, general health and infant care

How you can help:

Donate funds to help us meet our goal so we can build and furnish the clinic
Donate supplies: baby blankets, newborn apparel, medical supplies etc.Send them to: 

Spread the word! The more people who know about this cause, the more can help!

Funds will be used for:
Building materials: cement, sand, gravel, lumber, electrical wiring materials, nails, doors, windows, hinges, locks, paint, brushes, floor and wall tiles, etc (we already have roofing sheets, iron rods and part of the lumber)
Furniture: delivery beds, chairs, desks, shelves, tables, filing cabinets
Furnishings: ceiling fans, blankets, sheets, curtains, informational posters
Recording supplies: file folders, stationary, pens, record books
Medical Supplies: incubator, oxygen cylinder, drip/infusion pole, baby weighing scale, catgut, standing lamps, refrigerator for medicine, suction bulbs, stethoscope, fetoscope, gloves, surgery instruments, blood pressure cuff, hemostats, specula, forceps, needles, needle holders, catheters, rubber apron, syringes, gauze, disinfectant, episiotomy scissors, long scissors, umbilical scissors, cord clamps, etc
Our funding goal - $14,800 - is the bare bones estimate of what we will need to finish the clinic. Any additional funds will go to stocking extra or better equipment and materials for the clinic, or to training materials/sessions for the midwife and doctor.

story:
The Story 

A man's quest to overcome his fear of rejection by making at least one crazy request a day for 100 days was throttled last week when a Krispy Kreme employee accepted his order for five doughnuts linked together in the colors and shape of the Olympic symbol.

"It's only my third day and I have already failed," Jia Jiang wrote on his 100 Days of Rejection Therapy blog. "But I did so with such amazement and happiness."

When the 31-year-old approached the register to make his "specialized" doughnut order, Jackie Braun, a shift leader at an Austin, Texas, Krispy Kreme, asked him when he would need it.

"In the next 15 minutes," Jiang replied.

"I was honestly just hoping for a 'no' and to go home," Jiang told Yahoo News in an interview on Monday.

(Krispy Kreme)

Instead, Braun spent several minutes using the back of some receipt paper to diagram the unusual order.

"Let me see what I can do," she said.

Fifteen minutes later, she emerged with a Krispy Kreme box with the glazed Olympic ring arrangement inside—and, astonishingly, did not charge Jiang for it.

"It wasn't exactly what he wanted," Braun told Yahoo News. "To my eyes, it wasn't perfect, so I didn't think I should charge him for it. It was the best I could do in the time allotted."

"Wow, Jackie, I'm a fan," Jiang told her, on behalf of everyone in America.

"I was overwhelmed, I couldn't believe it," Jiang said. "I went home and tweeted to Krispy Kreme and blogged about it. I wanted the world to know about what she did."

A campaign to get Braun a raise and promotion was quickly launched in the Youtube comments section underneath Jiang's video.

"Jackie is awesome," more than one viewer wrote. "The world needs more people like her."

"Yo, if Krispy Kreme doesn't promote her to CEO I'm boycotting!" wrote another. "And I love doughnuts."

Jiang, who launched a Facebook page called "Give Jackie at Krispy Kreme a Raise," said he returned to Krispy Kreme on Sunday to thank Braun for going above and beyond the call of doughnut duty.

Braun, though, said she didn't do anything out of the ordinary.

"It was a simple thing," Braun, who's been with Krispy Kreme for five years, said. "The Olympic symbol was the only unusual part, because they're not on TV right now. But we do orders like that every day. We're here to make people happy."

How you can help!

Donate what you can! Even a dollar would go a long way in helping Jackie out! If you dont have the money you can still help out by sharing this page through various social media websites you use.

What This is For

Our goal is to help Jackie any way she needs right now whether that be a MUCH deserved vacation to helping with anything in her personal life!

The Story 
A man's quest to overcome his fear of rejection by making at least one crazy request a day for 100 days was throttled last week when a Krispy Kreme employee accepted his order for five doughnuts linked together in the colors and shape of the Olympic symbol.
"It's only my third day and I have already failed," Jia Jiang wrote on his 100 Days of Rejection Therapy blog. "But I did so with such amazement and happiness."
When the 31-year-old approached the register to make his "specialized" doughnut order, Jackie Braun, a shift leader at an Austin, Texas, Krispy Kreme, asked him when he would need it.
"In the next 15 minutes," Jiang replied.
"I was honestly just hoping for a 'no' and to go home," Jiang told Yahoo News in an interview on Monday.
(Krispy Kreme)
Instead, Braun spent several minutes using the back of some receipt paper to diagram the unusual order.
"Let me see what I can do," she said.
Fifteen minutes later, she emerged with a Krispy Kreme box with the glazed Olympic ring arrangement inside—and, astonishingly, did not charge Jiang for it.
"It wasn't exactly what he wanted," Braun told Yahoo News. "To my eyes, it wasn't perfect, so I didn't think I should charge him for it. It was the best I could do in the time allotted."
"Wow, Jackie, I'm a fan," Jiang told her, on behalf of everyone in America.
"I was overwhelmed, I couldn't believe it," Jiang said. "I went home and tweeted to Krispy Kreme and blogged about it. I wanted the world to know about what she did."
A campaign to get Braun a raise and promotion was quickly launched in the Youtube comments section underneath Jiang's video.
"Jackie is awesome," more than one viewer wrote. "The world needs more people like her."
"Yo, if Krispy Kreme doesn't promote her to CEO I'm boycotting!" wrote another. "And I love doughnuts."
Jiang, who launched a Facebook page called "Give Jackie at Krispy Kreme a Raise," said he returned to Krispy Kreme on Sunday to thank Braun for going above and beyond the call of doughnut duty.
Braun, though, said she didn't do anything out of the ordinary.
"It was a simple thing," Braun, who's been with Krispy Kreme for five years, said. "The Olympic symbol was the only unusual part, because they're not on TV right now. But we do orders like that every day. We're here to make people happy."


How you can help!
Donate what you can! Even a dollar would go a long way in helping Jackie out! If you dont have the money you can still help out by sharing this page through various social media websites you use.


What This is For
Our goal is to help Jackie any way she needs right now whether that be a MUCH deserved vacation to helping with anything in her personal life!

story:
ENGLISH VERSION-Click here


Un viaggio di ricerca nomade attraverso i resistenti alla modernità. Due antropologi non ancora famosi che vogliono imparare, documentare e diffondere un nuovo ma antico modo di vivere. Riscoprire antichi saperi, ricominciare a lavorare con le mani, ritrovare un equilibrio con il Pianeta.


Cosa vogliamo fare

Il nostro è un progetto di ricerca itinerante, un viaggio di (ri)scoperta. Attraverseremo l'Europa con i nostri taccuini, il nostro pc, foto e videocamera per scoprire comunità agricole, ecovillaggi e famiglie che hanno scelto di resistere alla modernità e condurre una vita meno legata al sistema consumistico.  Vogliamo analizzare e documentare quali strategie queste comunità adottano per organizzare la loro vita resistente.Tramite la condivisione del lavoro impareremo ciò che pensiamo possa tornare utile il giorno che decideremo di smettere di essere nomadi e di costruire una comunità sul modello di quelle incontrate. Quello che faremo sarà entrare in contatto e lavorare con persone che hanno già fatto questo tipo di scelta, imparare da loro come si può organizzare la vita in modo diverso e poi documentare, filmare e diffondere ciò che abbiamo imparato con gli appunti, le foto ed i video che pubblicheremo regolarmente sul blog. Questo per fare in modo che tutte le persone che ci hanno aiutato si sentano in viaggio insieme a noi, e possano poi raccontare ai loro figli di quella volta che hanno aiutato e seguito quei due folli in camper in giro per l'Europa. Al ritorno realizzeremo un documentario video sul nostro viaggio e stamperemo un libro con gli estratti più significativi dai nostri diari di viaggio e con le foto più belle. Alla fine del viaggio troveremo un posto dove applicare le conoscenze acquisite. Il viaggio ci permetterà di creare una rete di collaborazione e diffusione delle conoscenze tra le diverse comunità: questa rete sarà la base sociale da cui partire per il nostro futuro progetto di vita

I folli aprono le strade che poi i prudenti seguiranno.


Chi siamo


-Andrea Nasi: antropologo balcanista esperto in studi zingari. Tesi di laurea sull'impatto della società moderna nella cultura rom tradizionale. Progetto di ricerca per Terre des Hommes sulla migrazione dei rom romeni. Collaborazione e stesura progetti per diverse ong locali ed internazionali operanti nell'est europa con le popolazioni rom. Operatore sociale in un'associazione torinese che lavora per i diritti e l'integrazione dei rom romeni.


-Veronica Testa: antropologa africanista. Tesi di laurea sui riti di passaggio all'età adulta tra i Kabiyè del nord del Togo e sulle loro modificazioni portate dalla Chiesa cattolica. Con un "kot à projet" gestione e organizzazione di eventi volti alla conoscenza delle culture dell'Africa durante i tre anni di studi universitari in Belgio. Operatore sociale in un'associazione torinese che lavora per i diritti e l'integrazione dei rom romeni.


-Maelia Solim: meravigliosa bambina di quasi tre anni. Ha frequentato un anno di nido divertendosi moltissimo. Desidera crescere e imparare in famiglia. Vuole riempirsi gli occhi e le mani di vita. Socievole e amante del nomadismo e del camper.


Il Progetto

Nell'estate 2013 partiamo per la Romania insieme ad un fotografo comasco alla ricerca delle ultime famiglie di rom tradizionali nomadi. Ne troviamo alcune e ci fermiamo a vivere con loro per alcuni giorni. Una notte di festa intorno al fuoco nasce l'idea di abbandonare la vita stanziale per iniziare questo viaggio di ricerca itinerante.

Durante l'inverno abbiamo letto ed assimilato molti libri scritti da studiosi della decrescita, ambientalisti, esponenti del sustainable living, scienziati e biologi consci dello stato disastroso del Pianeta, critici del modello consumistico attuale, e anche di testimoni di un modo di vivere diverso ed alternativo a quello della nostra società dei consumi. Abbiamo preso coscienza della necessità di un cambio radicale nello stile di vita per poter adattare le nostre esigenze a quelle del Pianeta in cui viviamo ed alle società con cui conviviamo.


Il nostro progetto è pensato per tutti coloro che desiderano cambiare vita, Partendo dalla convinzione che le rivoluzioni cominciano con una goccia d'acqua, abbiamo deciso di essere i primi a fare questo passo. Ci siamo chiesti: "Che cosa posso fare per migliorare la mia vita e quella del Pianeta" ed abbiamo scelto di farlo in prima persona.

Non vogliamo creare la nostra piccola isola felice e disinteressarci dei problemi del mondo, ma tutto al contrario vogliamo dare il buon esempio, cominciare da dove si può, per non stare solo fermi a guardare bensì agire in prima persona.

ll nostro progetto è un master di studio pratico ed un terreno di ricerca sociale. Concentreremo i nostri sforzi per:

1) imparare le tecniche di produzione agricola (tecniche orticole, agricoltura sinergica, permacoltura, compostaggio, fitodepurazione).

2) imparare a fabbricare utensili e strutture utili (forno solare, compost toilet, forno in argilla ecc.).

3) analizzare come le diverse comunità organizzano la loro vita sociale (metodo decisionale, suddivisione del lavoro, gestione finanziaria).

4) studiare quale cammino educativo queste comunità hanno messo in pratica per i loro figli.

5) imparare una nuova organizzazione di vita nel rispetto e nella conservazione della biosfera (riduzione dell'impronta ecologica e dei consumi, riciclo e riutilizzo materiali, conservazione capitale naturale).

6) imparare, preservare e diffondere antiche conoscenze legate ad un sistema non consumistico.


Obiettivi della ricerca

Alla fine del nostro percorso elaboreremo uno studio di fattibilità di una comunità resistente, sviluppando ed approfondendo lungo il nostro percorso cinque punti chiave che ci siamo prefissati di analizzare nella nostra ricerca


Organizzazione

Analizzeremo come queste comunità organizzano la loro vita in comune, quindi la gestione degli spazi comuni quali cucina, sala giochi, pasti, lavanderia. Riteniamo importante che le comunità siano impostate sulla condivisione. Verranno approfonditi anche i metodi decisionali legati al lavoro che riteniamo dovrebbero essere basati sul consenso, e la suddivisione dei compiti, che dovrebbe essere equa e rispettare non solo le capacità ma anche i desideri di ciascuno.

Sostenibilità

Esamineremo la resilienza di queste comunità, cioè la loro capacita di adattamento alle diverse circostanze climatiche, sociali ed economiche. Questo attraverso la differenziazione delle attività, in quanto il presupposto è che quanto più una comunità è specializzata tanto meno è in grado di gestire le difficoltà. La resilienza è basata anche slla collaborazione con le altre comunità del territorio e sulla rete con le comunità al di fuori di esso. Considereremo quali tecniche usano per restituire il capitale naturale, tecniche che potrebbero includere la piantumazione degli alberi, il compostaggio e la preservazione dell'humus, e vari metodi di riciclo e riuso dei materiali.

Saperi tradizionali

Riteniamo che una comunità resistente debba riservare spazio alla scoperta ed allo sviluppo dei saperi tradizionali, attraverso un recupero della cultura dei vecchi ed uno stretto contatto con il territorio in cui sono. Questo prima che queste conoscenze scompaiano dalla memoria collettiva.

Autosufficienza

E' importante che queste comunità tendano all'autosufficienza, in primo luogo quella alimentare, legata alla produzione di cibo, che deve essere un'integrazione di orticoltura, seminativi, frutta e d allevamento. Altrettanto importante è l'autosufficienza energetica, che deve essere legata a piccoli sistemi integrati fra loro (microeolico, piccolo fotovoltaico, forni solari ecc). Infine l'autosufficienza è necessariamente legata all'autoproduzione di utensili e strutture.

Educazione

Una parte fondamentale del nostro studio riguarderà l'educazione, che dovrebbe essere pensata nel senso classico del termine: la paideia greca, cioè l'educazione alla cittadinanza. Innanzitutto l'educazione dei figli deve essere riconcettualizzata in modo che si rivaluti e si insegni lo spirito del dono, alla base della convivialità necessaria per la vita comune, e l'etica della natura, cioè la conservazione e la cura del capitale naturale. Studieremo quindi come queste comunità organizzano in pratica l'educazione dei bambini tramite laboratori pedagogici, homeschooling e come integrano queste attività con la scuola tradizionale. Visiteremo comunità con bambini perchè questo viaggio risulti un percorso educativo per la nostra bambina. Abbiamo scelto le comunità dove ci sono bambini per permettere a Maelia il confronto e la socializzazione con i suoi pari.


Bibliografia:

Ehrlich, P. e A., Il cambio della ruota. Risorse, popolazione, cultura, potere. Edizioni Ambiente, Milano, 2005.

Latouche, S., Per un'abbondanza frugale, Bollati Boringhieri, Torino 2012.

Latouche, S., Come sopravvivere allo sviluppo. Dalla decolonizzazione dell'immaginario economico alla costruzione di una società alternativa. Bollati Boringhieri, Torino 2005.

Latouche, S., Come si esce dalla società dei consumi. Corsi e percorsi per la decrescita. Bollati Boringhieri, Torino 2011.

Neufeld, G., Maté, G., I vostri figli hanno bisogno di voi,


Dove come quando e perchè, o i luoghi dove vogliamo fermarci ed imparare

Perchè nomadi? In molti ci hanno posto questa domanda. Potremmo imparare molte di queste cose senza spostarci troppo dalla nostra città natale. Indubbiamente i costi e i problemi si ridurrebbero molto, ma anche la ricchezza dell'esperienza. Abbiamo scelto di essere ricercatori itineranti:

1) Perchè pensiamo che il confronto tra diverse realtà arricchirà la nostra esperienza.

2) Perchè pensiamo che il viaggio rappresenti un'occasione unica per la nostra bambina di crescere ed imparare da nuove esperienze.

3) Perchè lavorando a contatto con diverse realtà potremo creare una rete locale, nazionale e internazionale di conoscenze e di collaborazione futura.

4) Perchè abbiamo letto numerose testimonianze di chi ha scelto una vita di resistenza e moltissimi lamentano un doloroso isolamento: speriamo di superarlo e di creare invece una fitta e viva rete umana di reciproco aiuto e di mutuo scambio.

5) Perchè è tramite il viaggio e la conoscenza di realtà lontane e differenti tra loro che si possono notare e scoprire punti di forza e di debolezza, che si possono cogliere i lati migliori, che si possono apprendere le più geniali strategie di vita.

Qui di seguito una lista dei luoghi che visiteremo durante gli anni di ricerca, la lista ovviamente, come in ogni ricerca sul campo, potrebbe essere riorientata in corso d'opera.


Dove andremo.

Inverno 2014: azienda agricola Il Giardino della Gioia,  Riesi, Caltanissetta, Sicilia.

Inverno 2015: Monastery Garden, Bakonybél, Veszprem, Hungary.

Primavera 2016: la Ferme du Collet, La Penne, Nice, Cote d'Azur, France.

Estate 2016: Cortijo el Paso, La Apujarra, Granada, Espana.

Autunno 2016: Vale Grifo, Lisbona, Portugal.

Inverno 2016: Quinta do Barbeito, Braga, Porto, Portugal.

Primavera 2017: Ferma Senra, Galicia, Espana.

10 linee guida.

  1. La nostra casa sarà il camper.

  2. Spenderemo il meno possibile affidandoci all'ospitalità delle comunità dove faremo ricerca. Tutto ciò che ci verrà offerto lo ripagheremo in lavoro. La rete wwoofing sarà la prediletta.

  3. Applicheremo la raccolta differenziata ed il riuso e riciclo.

  4. Diffonderemo tramite la rete internet tutto ciò che impareremo, vi terremo aggiornati sull'evoluzione di ciò che acquisiremo in conoscenza.

  5. Ogni backer verrà con noi: scriveremo il nome di ognuno sul lato del camper.

  6. Lavoreremo duro, non dimenticheremo che questo viaggio è una grande occasione di lavoro.

  7. Seguiremo il ciclo delle stagioni.

  8. Ci sposteremo in diverse realtà per conoscerne limiti e punti di forza ed imparare da ognuna di esse.

  9. A conclusione del viaggio creeremo un libro e un documentario video. Sarà il nostro ringraziamento più grande ai backer.

  10. Seguiremo una dieta vegetariana.


Soldi...

A cosa ci servono?


Non abbiamo sponsor per il nostro progetto, e dunque vi investiremo tutti i nostri risparmi per farlo diventare realtà. Con questi riusciremo ad affrontare le principali spese di vita durante gli anni di viaggio, e saranno anni improntati alla semplicità e alla riduzione di ogni spesa.

Con questa campagna di crowdfunding chiediamo il vostro aiuto per acquistare ciò che ancora ci manca per poter concretamente partire: il camper che vedete qui sopra, un Mercedes 407 del 1982. Chiediamo anche un contributo per l'acquisto della foto-videocamera e di un laptop. Tutti i soldi che eventualmente arriveranno in più li useremo per l'attrezzatura necessaria al viaggio e per tutte le altre spese. Anche nell'acquisto di questi oggetti manterremo il nostro impegno nel ridurre il più possibile le spese.  

Camper: 4000 Euro

Macchina fotografica e videocamera, laptop: 500 Euro.

Se riusciamo a superare il goal di 4500 euro ogni centesimo in più sarà speso per acquistare: cassetta degli attrezzi, kit pronto soccorso, bombole del gas, sacchi a pelo, ricambi del camper, abiti da lavoro, scarpe da trekking, torce, bussola, mappe e, naturalmente, gasolio per il camper e biglietti autostradali..

BAREFOOT RAMBLERS


A rambling research journey of discovery among resistants to modernity. Two anthropologists not yet famous want to learn, record and spread a new but old way of life. Rediscover ancient wisdom and skills, get back to working with their hands, finding a balance with the planet.


What we want to do.

Our research project is an exploring journey. We will cross Europe with our notebooks, our pc, photo and video cameras to discover farm communities, eco-villages and families who have chosen to resist modernity and lead a life less tied to the consumer system. By sharing work we will learn what we think will be useful  the day we decide to stop being nomads and to build a community on the model of those encountered.

What we will do is get in touch and work with people who have already made this kind of choice, learn from them how you can organize your life in a different way and then document, film and spread what we have learned with notes, photos and videos that we will post regularly on the blog. This is to make all the people who helped us feel on the road with us, and then one day they can tell their children about that time when they have helped and followed those two fools in camper around Europe. On the way back we will release a video documentary of our trip and we will print a book with the best pictures and quotes from our road trip journal. 

At the end of the trip we will find a place to apply their knowledge and begin our lives as resistants. The trip will allow us to create a network of cooperation and knowledge between different communities: this network will be the social  base to project our future life.

Fools open roads which cautious will follow.

Who we are.


-Andrea Nasi Anthropologist expert in Gypsy studies. Thesis on the impact of modern society on traditional Roma culture. Researcher for Terre des Hommes in Romania. Collaboration and writing projects for several local and international NGOs operating in Eastern Europe with the Roma populations. Social worker in a company that works for rights and integration of Roma people.


-Veronica Testa Africanist anthropologist. Thesis on the rites of passage into adulthood among Kabiyè of northern Togo and their modifications brought by the Catholic Church. With a "kot à projet" management and organization of events aimed at knowledge of the cultures of Africa during the three years of university studies in Belgium. Social worker in a company that works for rights and integration of Roma people.


-Maelia Solim Marvellous girl of nearly three years. She attended one year of kindergarden, which she loved. She  wants to grow and learn with family. She wants to fill her eyes and her hands with real life. Sociable, nomadism-lover and camper-lover.


The project.

In the summer of 2013 we went to Romania together with a photographer looking for the last traditional nomadic Roma families. We found some and we stopped to live with them for a few days. During a night party by the campfire we decided to abandon the settled life to begin this journey of travel and discovery.


During the winter we have been reading many books written by scholars of degrowth, environmentalists, representatives of sustainable living, scientists and biologists. All these people are aware of the dire state of the planet, they are critics of the current consumer model, and also witness a different way of living, an alternative way to our consumer society. We have become aware of the need for a radical change in lifestyle to fit our needs to those of the planet in which we live in.

Our project is designed for those who wish to change their lives.  Based on the conviction that revolutions begin with a drop of water, we decided to be the first to take this step. We asked ourselves, "What can we do to improve our lives and that of the planet?" and we decided to do it in the first person.

We do not want to create our own little happy island and start to ignore the world's problems, but on the contrary we want to give the good example and start doing what we can. We don't want to stay still doing nothing, but on the contrary we want to start working with our hands.

Our project is  a master of practical studies and a social researching field.

We will focus on:

1) learning the techniques of agricultural production (horticultural techniques, synergistic agriculture, permaculture, composting, phytodepuration) 

2) learning how to make tools and eco-facilities (solar oven, compost toilet, clay oven etc.)

3) analyzing how different communities organize their social life (decision-making, work division, financial management). 

4) studying the educational paths that these communities have chosen for their children.

5) learning a new life organization in the respect and preservation of the biosphere (reduction of the ecological footprint and consumption, recycling and reusing materials, conservation of natural capital). 

6) learning, preserving and spreading ancient knowledge related to a non-consumption system.


Where, when, how and why, or the places where we want to stop and learn. 

Why nomads? Many people have asked us this question. We could learn many of these things without moving too far from our hometown. Undoubtedly costs and problems would be reduced a lot, but so would the richness of the experience. We chose to be itinerant researchers: 

1) Because we do think that the comparison among different realities will enrich so much our experience.

2) Because working on different experiences can create a local, national and international network of knowledge and future cooperation. 

3) Because we read numerous stories of those who have chosen this kind of existence and many complain about isolation: we hope to overcome it and to instead create a dense and lively human network of mutual aid and mutual exchange

4) Because it is by travelling and getting to know distant and different realities that we can see and discover the strengths and weaknesses of all of them. It's the best way to catch the best side of things, the best way to learn the most brilliant life strategies. 

Below is a list of the places we will visit during the years of research, the list of course, as in any field research, could be redirected during the work in progress.


Where to.

Fall 2014:  Luna Nera farming, Greve in Chianti, Siena, Toscana.

Winter 2014:  Il Giardino della Gioia farming, Riesi, Caltanissetta, Sicilia.

Spring 2015:  Greece Project 037, Ionian Island, Greece. 

Summer 2015: Baza Ulmu, Baia Mare, Maramures, Romania.

Fall 2015: Happy-Clappy Farm, Cluj, Ardeal, Romania.

Spring 2016: Monastery Garden, Bakonybél, Veszprem, Hungary. 

Summer 2016: Cortijo el Paso, La Apujarra, Granada, Espana.

Fall 2016: Vale Grifo, Lisbona, Portugal.

Winter 2016: Quinta do Barbeito, Braga, Porto, Portugal.

Spring 2017: Ferma Senra, Galicia, Espana.

Summer 2017: Les Sabots de Lure, Drome, France.

Fall 2017: La Ferme du Collet, La Penne, Nice, Cote d'Azur, France.

Winter 2017: Amaltea Organic Farm, Rivalto-Chianni, Pisa, Toscana.


Our 10 guidelines.

1. Our home will be the camper van.

2. We will spend as little as possible by leaning on the hospitality of the communities we study. Everything that will be offered we will trade for handwork. The wwoofing network will be the favourite. 

3. We will do waste sorting, recycling and reusing. 

4. We will spread through the internet everything we will learn and we will keep you up to date on what are taught. 

5. Any supporter will come with us: we write everyone's name on the camper truck.

6. We will work hard, we will not forget that this journey is a great opportunity of work.

7. We will follow the seasonal cycle. 

8. We will move among different situations to know the limits and strengths and learn from each of them. 

9. At the end of the trip we will create a documentary video. It will be our biggest thanks to all the supporters and a way to make all the supporters just like as they are travelling with us. 

10. We will follow a vegetarian diet.


Bucks...

What do we need them for?


We do not have sponsors for our project, therefore we will invest all our savings to make it come true. With our savings we will be able to face the majority of our life's expenses during the years of travel. It will be years marked by simplicity and reduction of costs. 

With this crowdfunding campaign we are asking for your help to buy what we are still missing to be able to actually go and leave: the camper in the picture above, a wonderful 1982 Mercedes 407, the camera and a laptop. Any other fund that will come exceeding our goal will be spent to buy the equipment to travel. Even in the purchase of these items we will maintain our commitment to minimize expenses. 

Camper van: 4000 euros

Camera and laptop: 500 Euro

If we reach our goal every cent over 4500 euro will be spent for: tool kit, gas bottles, camper parts, first aid kit, sleeping bags, flashlights, compass, maps, work clothes, trekking shoes and, of course, fuel and highway fees...


How to contribute:


If you want to donate by credit card without opening a PayPal account, just click CONTRIBUTE, choose the perk, click GO TO PAYPAL, click "Pay with credit card" and fill in the form and uncheck "Save this information with PayPal account "and proceed with the payment.

If you want to donate but do not have neither a credit card nor a prepaid card, you can make an online bank transfer to this account number: IT27U0358901600010570359999 payable to Veronica Testa, Via Roma 9 / g Baldissero Torinese, Italia

ENGLISH VERSION-Click here








Un
viaggio di ricerca nomade attraverso i resistenti alla modernità. Due
antropologi non ancora famosi che vogliono imparare, documentare e
diffondere un nuovo ma antico modo di vivere. Riscoprire antichi
saperi, ricominciare a lavorare con le mani, ritrovare un equilibrio
con il Pianeta.


Cosa
vogliamo fare

Il
nostro è un progetto di ricerca itinerante, un viaggio di
(ri)scoperta. Attraverseremo l'Europa con i nostri taccuini, il
nostro pc, foto e videocamera per scoprire comunità agricole,
ecovillaggi e famiglie che hanno scelto di resistere alla modernità
e condurre una vita meno legata al sistema consumistico.  Vogliamo analizzare e documentare quali strategie queste comunità adottano per organizzare la loro vita resistente.Tramite la condivisione del lavoro impareremo
ciò che pensiamo possa tornare utile il giorno che decideremo di
smettere di essere nomadi e di costruire una comunità sul modello di
quelle incontrate. Quello che faremo sarà entrare in contatto e
lavorare con persone che hanno già fatto questo tipo di scelta,
imparare da loro come si può organizzare la vita in modo diverso e
poi documentare, filmare e diffondere ciò che abbiamo imparato con
gli appunti, le foto ed i video che pubblicheremo regolarmente sul
blog. Questo per fare in modo che tutte le persone che ci hanno aiutato si sentano in viaggio insieme a noi, e possano poi raccontare ai loro figli di quella volta che hanno aiutato e seguito quei due folli in camper in giro per l'Europa. Al ritorno realizzeremo un documentario video sul nostro
viaggio e stamperemo un libro con gli estratti più significativi dai nostri diari di viaggio e con le foto più belle. Alla fine del viaggio troveremo un posto dove applicare le
conoscenze acquisite. Il
viaggio ci permetterà di creare una rete di collaborazione e diffusione
delle conoscenze tra le diverse comunità: questa rete sarà la base
sociale da cui partire per il nostro futuro progetto di vita
I folli aprono le strade che poi i prudenti seguiranno.
Chi
siamo

-Andrea
Nasi: antropologo balcanista esperto in studi zingari. Tesi di
laurea sull'impatto della società moderna nella cultura rom
tradizionale. Progetto di ricerca per Terre des Hommes sulla
migrazione dei rom romeni. Collaborazione e stesura progetti per
diverse ong locali ed internazionali operanti nell'est europa con le popolazioni rom. Operatore sociale in un'associazione torinese che lavora per i diritti e l'integrazione dei rom romeni.



-Veronica
Testa: antropologa africanista. Tesi di laurea sui riti di
passaggio all'età adulta tra i Kabiyè del nord del Togo e sulle
loro modificazioni portate dalla Chiesa cattolica. Con un "kot à
projet" gestione e organizzazione di eventi volti alla
conoscenza delle culture dell'Africa durante i tre anni di studi
universitari in Belgio. Operatore sociale in un'associazione torinese
che lavora per i diritti e l'integrazione dei rom romeni.



-Maelia
Solim:
meravigliosa bambina di quasi tre anni. Ha frequentato un anno di
nido divertendosi moltissimo. Desidera crescere e imparare in
famiglia. Vuole riempirsi gli occhi e le mani di vita. Socievole e
amante del nomadismo e del camper.



Il
Progetto

Nell'estate
2013 partiamo per la Romania insieme ad un fotografo comasco alla
ricerca delle ultime famiglie di rom tradizionali nomadi. Ne troviamo
alcune e ci fermiamo a vivere con loro per alcuni giorni. Una notte
di festa intorno al fuoco nasce l'idea di abbandonare la vita
stanziale per iniziare questo viaggio di ricerca itinerante.
Durante l'inverno abbiamo letto ed assimilato molti libri scritti da studiosi della decrescita, ambientalisti,
esponenti del sustainable living, scienziati e biologi consci dello
stato disastroso del Pianeta, critici del modello consumistico
attuale, e anche di testimoni di un modo di vivere diverso ed
alternativo a quello della nostra società dei consumi. Abbiamo preso
coscienza della necessità di un cambio radicale nello stile di vita
per poter adattare le nostre esigenze a quelle del Pianeta in cui
viviamo ed alle società con cui conviviamo.
Il
nostro progetto è pensato per tutti coloro che desiderano cambiare
vita, Partendo dalla
convinzione che le rivoluzioni cominciano con una goccia d'acqua,
abbiamo deciso di essere i primi a fare questo passo. Ci siamo chiesti: "Che cosa posso fare per migliorare la mia vita e
quella del Pianeta" ed abbiamo scelto di farlo in prima persona. 
Non vogliamo creare la nostra piccola isola felice e disinteressarci dei problemi del mondo, ma tutto al contrario vogliamo dare il buon esempio, cominciare da dove si può, per non stare solo fermi a guardare bensì agire in prima persona.

ll nostro progetto è un master di studio pratico ed
un terreno di ricerca sociale. Concentreremo i nostri sforzi per:

1)
imparare le tecniche di produzione agricola (tecniche orticole,
agricoltura sinergica, permacoltura, compostaggio, fitodepurazione).

2)
imparare a fabbricare utensili e strutture utili (forno solare,
compost toilet, forno in argilla ecc.).

3)
analizzare come le diverse comunità organizzano la loro vita sociale (metodo decisionale, suddivisione del lavoro, gestione finanziaria).

4)
studiare quale cammino educativo queste comunità hanno messo in
pratica per i loro figli.

5)
imparare una nuova organizzazione di vita nel rispetto e nella
conservazione della biosfera (riduzione dell'impronta ecologica e dei consumi, riciclo e riutilizzo materiali, conservazione capitale naturale).

6)
imparare, preservare e diffondere antiche conoscenze legate ad un
sistema non consumistico.Obiettivi della ricercaAlla fine del nostro percorso elaboreremo uno studio di fattibilità di una comunità resistente, sviluppando ed approfondendo lungo il nostro percorso cinque punti chiave che ci siamo prefissati di analizzare nella nostra ricercaOrganizzazioneAnalizzeremo come queste comunità organizzano la loro vita in comune, quindi la gestione degli spazi comuni quali cucina, sala giochi, pasti, lavanderia. Riteniamo importante che le comunità siano impostate sulla condivisione. Verranno approfonditi anche i metodi decisionali legati al lavoro che riteniamo dovrebbero essere basati sul consenso, e la suddivisione dei compiti, che dovrebbe essere equa e rispettare non solo le capacità ma anche i desideri di ciascuno.SostenibilitàEsamineremo la resilienza di queste comunità, cioè la loro capacita di adattamento alle diverse circostanze climatiche, sociali ed economiche. Questo attraverso la differenziazione delle attività, in quanto il presupposto è che quanto più una comunità è specializzata tanto meno è in grado di gestire le difficoltà. La resilienza è basata anche slla collaborazione con le altre comunità del territorio e sulla rete con le comunità al di fuori di esso. Considereremo quali tecniche usano per restituire il capitale naturale, tecniche che potrebbero includere la piantumazione degli alberi, il compostaggio e la preservazione dell'humus, e vari metodi di riciclo e riuso dei materiali.Saperi tradizionaliRiteniamo che una comunità resistente debba riservare spazio alla scoperta ed allo sviluppo dei saperi tradizionali, attraverso un recupero della cultura dei vecchi ed uno stretto contatto con il territorio in cui sono. Questo prima che queste conoscenze scompaiano dalla memoria collettiva.AutosufficienzaE' importante che queste comunità tendano all'autosufficienza, in primo luogo quella alimentare, legata alla produzione di cibo, che deve essere un'integrazione di orticoltura, seminativi, frutta e d allevamento. Altrettanto importante è l'autosufficienza energetica, che deve essere legata a piccoli sistemi integrati fra loro (microeolico, piccolo fotovoltaico, forni solari ecc). Infine l'autosufficienza è necessariamente legata all'autoproduzione di utensili e strutture.EducazioneUna parte fondamentale del nostro studio riguarderà l'educazione, che dovrebbe essere pensata nel senso classico del termine: la paideia greca, cioè l'educazione alla cittadinanza. Innanzitutto l'educazione dei figli deve essere riconcettualizzata in modo che si rivaluti e si insegni lo spirito del dono, alla base della convivialità necessaria per la vita comune, e l'etica della natura, cioè la conservazione e la cura del capitale naturale. Studieremo quindi come queste comunità organizzano in pratica l'educazione dei bambini tramite laboratori pedagogici, homeschooling e come integrano queste attività con la scuola tradizionale. Visiteremo comunità con bambini perchè questo viaggio risulti un percorso educativo per la nostra bambina. Abbiamo scelto le comunità dove ci sono bambini per permettere a Maelia il confronto e la socializzazione con i suoi pari.
Bibliografia:Crisi socioeconomica e azioni positive di resilienza

silenziosa. I diari di Pratale, Racconti di una vita diversa.

vs quantità. Dalla decrescita ad una nuova economia. Orme
